docs.lead_paragraph: Douglas Almond, a Columbia University economist who has studied the effects of the Chernobyl disaster, is concerned that the Japanese government may not be doing enough to warn pregnant women to leave any areas at risk of radiation exposure. Those areas can be much farther from the nuclear plants than many people realize.
docs.abstract: "The Japanese government should be issuing stronger warnings to pregnant women," an economist says, citing research about the effects of the Chernobyl disaster on Swedish fetuses.
docs.snippet: "The Japanese government should be issuing stronger warnings to pregnant women," an economist says, citing research about the effects of the Chernobyl disaster on Swedish fetuses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kara Goucher, who gave birth to a son last September, will be running in the New York City half-marathon next Sunday.

headline.print_headline: For Runner, Motherhood Humbles and Inspires

docs.abstract: Excerpts from 30 Seconds Q&A with marathon runner Kara Goucher, who is returning to competitive running less than six months after giving birth.

docs.lead_paragraph: For seven years, Josh Winters partied with the Mideast elite and lived to tell about it. This is the story of a person who does not claim to be a fighter for patriotic causes, a political leader or diplomat, it is merely a story of an ordinary citizen, who found himself thrust into the midst of events he had no choice but to be a part of - events he could neither evade or distance himself from, as they unfolded. This is just a story of a Yemeni citizen.''- Mohsin Alaini from his book, '' 50 Years in Shifting Sands,'' translated by Hassan al-Haifi.
docs.abstract: Josh Winters describes some of his experiences during the seven years he spent among Mideast elite at invitation of Haitham Alaini, whose father, Mohsin, was Yemen's prime minister; photos (L)
